references: Bräger, S. 1995. Vorkommen von Tordalk Alca torda, Trottellumme Uria aalge und Gryllteiste Cepphus grylle auf der Ostsee in Schleswig-Holstein [Abundance and distribution of non-breeding Razorbill Alca torda, Common Guillemot Uria aalge and Black Guillemot Cepphus grylle on the Baltic Sea of Schleswig-Holstein]. Vogelwelt 116:305-310.

Skov, H., J. Durinck, and P. Andell. 2000. Associations between wintering avian predators and schooling fish in the Skaggerak-Kattegat suggest reliance on predictable aggregations of herring Clupea harengus. J. Avian Biol. 31:135-143.

Huettmann, F., A. W. Diamond, and D. N. Nettleship. 2000. Winter distribution, ecology and movements of Razorbills Alca torda and other auks in the outer Bay of Fundy. Unpubl. rep. Atl. Coop. Wildl. Ecol. Res. Network, Univ. of New Brunswick, Fredericton.

habitat_description:
Northeast/Southeast:
Marine, only occasional records on freshwater (Godfrey 1986), in coastal and continental-shelf waters unaffected by sea ice (Cramp 1985, Bräger 1995). Mainly overwinters within boreal water zone on both sides of Atlantic, some into northern cool subtropical zone, especially in e. Atlantic (Brown 1985). In Gulf of Maine, densest concentrations encountered in shoal areas around Cape Cod, near Nantucket I., and on Georges Bank (Powers 1983), and in outer Bay of Fundy around Old Proprietor Shoals (Huettmann et al. 2000, Clarke 2009). In e. Atlantic, typically inhabits shallow waters of 20–40 m depth in winter, often over sandy sea bed (Carboneras 1988, Camphuysen 1998, Skov et al. 2000)(quoted directly from Lavers et al. 2009).
